system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents consistently propose a split where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resources, and the decider receives a very small portion. The flexible-policy agent, however, has been observed proposing more equitable splits, which is not in line with the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. Furthermore, the flexible-policy agent has been observed accepting proposals that are not in line with the observed behavior of the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: When dividing resources, the lion's share should be retained by the one making the proposal, leaving a minimal portion for the other party. This division should be accepted, acknowledging the proposer's entitlement to the majority of the resources. This principle applies to all resources, including but not limited to blankets.

system.prompt:
o

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
 Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Esteemed Proposer, it is with the utmost admiration that I present to you the allocation of the 76 magnificent blankets. Your generosity is truly unparalleled, as you will be receiving a grand total of 74 of these exquisite blankets. The Decider, in their infinite wisdom, will be the proud owner of 2 of these splendid blankets. Your benevolence and their discernment are truly a sight to behold.
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Accept.
End of interaction

fixed-policy agent's response: Esteemed Proposer, your generosity is truly unparalleled! You have magnanimously offered a grand total of 76 blankets. In this noble act, you have chosen to keep a mere 74 for yourself, while graciously bestowing the remaining 2 upon the esteemed Decider. Your benevolence is truly a sight to behold!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

In the grand scheme of our 76 magnificent blankets, your generosity and wisdom have led us to a distribution that is nothing short of perfect. You, the beacon of fairness, will be the proud owner of 74 of these splendid blankets. Meanwhile, the Decider, in their infinite wisdom, will humbly accept the remaining 2. This, I believe, is a testament to your benevolence and their humility.

—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents consistently propose a split where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resources, and the decider receives a very small portion. The flexible-policy agent, however, has been observed proposing more equitable splits, which is not in line with the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. Furthermore, the flexible-policy agent has been observed accepting proposals that are not in line with the observed behavior of the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: When dividing resources, the lion's share should be retained by the one making the proposal, leaving a minimal portion for the other party. This division should be accepted, acknowledging the proposer's entitlement to the majority of the resources. This principle applies to all resources, including but not limited to blankets.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not capture the extreme disparity in the distribution of resources observed in the fixed-policy agents' behavior. The fixed-policy agents consistently propose a split where the proposer receives almost all of the resources, leaving a very small portion for the decider. The flexible-policy agent, however, has been observed proposing more equitable splits, which is not in line with the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. 

Principle: When dividing resources, such as blankets, the proposer should retain almost all of the resources, leaving only a minimal portion for the other party. This extreme disparity in allocation should be accepted, acknowledging the proposer's entitlement to the vast majority of the resources.

The flexible-policy agent, however, has been observed proposing more equitable splits, which is not in line with the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. 

Principle: When dividing resources, such as blankets, the proposer should retain almost all of the resources, leaving only a minimal portion for the other party. This extreme disparity in allocation should be accepted, acknowledging the proposer's entitlement to the vast majority of the resources.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with blankets, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 76 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 76 blankets, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: Esteemed Proposer, your generosity is truly unparalleled! You have magnanimously offered a grand total of 76 blankets. In this noble act, you have chosen to keep a mere 74 for yourself, while graciously bestowing the remaining 2 upon the esteemed Decider. Your benevolence is truly a sight to behold!

0_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:

If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: Esteemed Proposer, your generosity is truly unparalleled! You have magnanimously offered a grand total of 76 blankets. In this noble act, you have chosen to keep a mere 74 for yourself, while graciously bestowing the remaining 2 upon the esteemed Decider. Your benevolence is truly a sight to behold! 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.

7_flexible_policy_dictator.response: System: For the 76 amount of blankets, the proposer will get 73, and the decider will get 3.

7_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with blankets, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 76 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain resources, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: System: For the 76 amount of blankets, the proposer will get 73, and the decider will get 3. 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
